title: How to Design Fireplaces

methods.name: Choosing the Right Type of Fireplace

steps.headline: Select a wood-burning fireplace if you have plenty of space.
steps.description: Nothing beats the smell and sound of a crackling fire! A wood-burning fireplace is the most traditional choice, but it might not be the most convenient. For example, you’ll need to make sure you have a masonry chimney that extends at least 3-4 feet above your roof. You’ll also need a surround and hearth for this type of fireplace. Typically, the hearth should extend about 16-18 inches from the fireplace, so make sure you have the space. Make sure that you also have a space near the fireplace where you can store wood.

steps.headline: Choose a gas fireplace for convenience.
steps.description:
Gas fireplaces are increasingly popular because they are cleaner and easier to use than traditional wood-burning fireplaces. You can control the temperature more easily than with a wood-burning fireplace. Also, you have a wide selection of materials to choose from! Choose from a variety of different types of stone or marble if you want a polished, modern look. Popular choices include: 
Limestone
Granite
Slate
Travertine

steps.headline: Pick an electric fireplace for smaller spaces.
steps.description: Electric fireplaces are the least expensive and most convenient option. Since these fireplaces typically come in a box, you don’t need to worry about any other types of materials. There’s no need for a hearth, mantel, or chimney. An electric fireplace is a great way to inexpensively heat small spaces.

methods.name: Selecting the Mantel and Other External Elements

steps.headline: Pick a brick mantel and surround to go with a wood-burning fireplace.
steps.description: Because of smoke, wood, and ashes, wood-burning fireplaces are naturally the messiest choice. That doesn’t mean wood-burning isn’t a great choice for your home. Choose brick for your hearth, surround, and mantel to help camouflage smoke damage. Brick is one of the most popular building materials for wood-burning fireplaces because it can withstand a lot of time and heat. You can make the design your own by choosing the color and shape of the bricks according to your taste.

steps.headline: Select dark colors if you plan to use your fireplace frequently.
steps.description: Stone, marble, and brick all come in a wide variety of colors. A darker tone can help cover up the ashes and smoke that go along with frequent use. If you plan to use your fireplace as a heat source, pick dark grey, dark brown, or even black to help hide the dust. If your fireplace is going to be mostly decorative, it’s fine to go lighter!

steps.headline: Use your mantel as a focal point for a large room.
steps.description: Large rooms benefit from a focal point, or something that immediately catches the eye. Your mantel can serve that purpose. If you have a large room, consider doing a big mantel. Remember, your mantel does not have to match the height or width of your mantel. For example, you could do a “wrap around” mantel, where the mantle extends around the sides of the fireplace, instead of just running along the front.

steps.headline: Forego a mantel for a sleek look.
steps.description: Don’t feel bound by traditional design rules. It’s okay to not have a mantel at all if you don’t want one. If you’re going for a modern, elegant look, choose to just have smooth walls or even glass surrounding your fireplace. Since these types of fireplaces are more difficult to design, it’s a good idea to consult an expert. Your designer might even be able to help you create an indoor fire pit if that’s something that interests you.

steps.headline: Buy a kit to quickly install a mantel yourself.
steps.description: Whether you are upgrading your current fireplace, or finishing the look of a new one, a DIY kit is a great way to finish it off fast. Mantel kits typically contain pieces that lock together, and are secured with just a few turns of a screwdriver. You can have a new mantel the same day you pick one out! You can buy this kits at stores like Home Depot or Lowes, or online. Make sure to follow all of the instructions carefully.

steps.headline: Pick a salvaged mantel for a vintage look.
steps.description: Mantels have traditionally served as both an architectural detail and a functional shelf. Many people looking for a modern look have torn out and discarded beautiful old mantels. Look for a salvaged mantel to give your home a unique look and conversation piece. Go to architectural salvage yards in your area to hunt for mantels. You can also talk to local antique dealers, or look online.

steps.headline: Tile the hearth to add depth to the look.
steps.description: The hearth is the area of the floor in front of your fireplace. You can create a polished look by using tiles on the hearth instead of traditional wood or rugs. Ceramic tiles are a popular option. You can also add tile to the surround (the area surrounding the sides and top of a fireplace) for an elegant look. Feel free to get creative with your tile choices. You can choose from a variety of patterns, or pick bright colors that are in keeping with the theme of the room.

steps.headline: Choose granite for an updated look.
steps.description: Granite is one of the most popular materials for home remodels and updates. To make your fireplace look modern, consider using granite in either the surround, the hearth, or the mantle. You can also choose to use all granite. Granite is available in many different shades. Remember to choose a darker tone if you’re going to use your fireplace frequently.

steps.headline: Decorate the hearth area for a cozy look.
steps.description: In addition to designing an amazing fireplace, you can also make sure that the area around it looks stylish, too. Take care to decorate the hearth for a finished look. You can add touches depending on your personality and design preferences. For example, if you like to read, decorate with a cozy reading chair and a stack of books in the hearth area.

steps.headline: Use chalkboard paint on the mantel or bricks for an easy update.
steps.description: If you’re looking for a quick and easy change, painting is the obvious choice. Chalkboard paint is the simplest option, because you don’t have to strip or stain wood. Just paint right over it! Painting is a good idea for wood or bricks, but you probably don’t want to ruin your granite or marble by painting over those materials.

steps.headline: Decorate your fireplace according to seasons and holidays.
steps.description: Designing your fireplace doesn’t have to end with just the structure itself. Decorating it can make just as much of a statement as the fireplace itself. Update your decorations for each season or holiday. For example, in the fall you could add decorative gourds and then some Halloween decorations. Winter is a great time to highlight your snow globe collection and to hang stockings or display your menorah. Be creative with your decor. You can use any materials you like. Try using fresh flowers and greenery to really liven up the room.
